author: Artificial Analysis
text:
Moonshot‚Äôs Kimi K2.5 is the new leading open weights model, now closer than ever to the frontier - with only OpenAI, Anthropic and Google models ahead

Key takeaways:

‚û§ Impressive performance on agentic tasks: @Kimi_Moonshot's Kimi K2.5 achieves an Elo of 1309 on our GDPval-AA evaluation, behind only OpenAI and Anthropic models. Kimi K2.5 leaps ahead of GLM-4.7, DeepSeek V3.2 and Gemini 3 Pro. GDPval-AA is our leading metric for general agentic performance, measuring the performance of models on realistic knowledge work tasks such as preparing presentations and analysis. Models are given shell access and web browsing capabilities in an agentic loop via our reference agentic harness called Stirrup.

‚û§ Native multimodality for the first time: Kimi K2.5 is the first flagship model from Moonshot to support multimodal (image and video) inputs. This is the first time that the leading open weights model has supported image input, removing a critical barrier to the adoption of open weights models compared to proprietary models from the frontier labs. It represents significant differentiation for Kimi K2.5 compared to other open weights leaders including DeepSeek V3.2, GLM-4.7, MiniMax M2.1 and MiMo-V2-Flash. Kimi K2.5 scores 75% on the MMMU Pro visual reasoning benchmark, slightly behind Gemini 3 Pro but in line with GPT-5.2 and Claude Opus 4.5.

‚û§ Moderate cost to run Artificial Analysis Intelligence Index: Kimi K2.5 lands at $371 in Cost to Run Artificial Analysis Intelligence Index, more than 4x cheaper than Claude Opus 4.5 and GPT-5.2, but more than 5x more expensive than DeepSeek V3.2 and gpt-oss-120b.

‚û§ Moderate token usage: Kimi K2.5 demonstrates token usage comparable to other models in the same intelligence tier, using ~82M reasoning tokens across the Artificial Analysis Intelligence Index evaluation suite. This is slightly lower than Kimi K2 Thinking (~95M reasoning tokens) and much lower than GLM 4.7 (~160M reasoning tokens).

‚û§ Open weights: Kimi K2.5 is an MoE model with 1T total parameters and 32B active. Similar to Kimi K2 Thinking, Kimi K2.5 has been released in native INT4 precision rather than FP8/BF16. This means the model is only ~595GB.

‚û§ Hybrid reasoning: Kimi K2.5 unifies Moonshot‚Äôs reasoning and non-reasoning models into a single model. We have evaluated K2.5 with reasoning on (and will share results soon with reasoning off).

‚û§ Low hallucination rate: Kimi K2.5 scores -11 on the AA-Omniscience Index, our knowledge evaluation measuring both accuracy and hallucination rate. This score is primarily driven by a comparatively low hallucination rate of 64% (reduced from Kimi K2 Thinking‚Äôs 74%), indicating a slightly greater tendency to abstain rather than fabricate knowledge when the model is uncertain.

author: Rohan Paul
text:
üßµ 4/n. The feature I think is the most powerful for Superagent is the multiple concurrent sub-agent architecture.

Instead of trying to solve your problem alone, the system instantly acts like a manager by spinning up 20 specialized agents to tackle different parts of the job at the exact same time. 

This parallel work is the standout feature because it allows the AI to complete massive, multi-angle research projects that would normally overwhelm a standard, single-track model.

author: The Kobeissi Letter
text:
Silver ETF trading volume is exploding:

Trading volume in the largest silver-backed ETF, $SLV, hit a record $40 billion on Monday.

This marks the highest turnover among any other asset and is 15 TIMES its average daily volume.

This also TRIPLES the previous peak seen in 2011.

By comparison, the S&P 500 ETF, $SPY, traded $25 billion, the Nasdaq 100 ETF, $QQQ, $17 billion, while Nvidia, $NVDA, and Tesla, $TSLA, each traded $16 billion.

Furthermore, the 2x leverage long-silver futures ETF, $AGQ, posted $8 billion in volume yesterday.

The largest Gold ETF, $GLD, also saw massive turnover of $13 billion, but $27 BILLION lower than $SLV.

Silver's recent moves are truly unprecedented.

author: EMARKETER

author: Steve Hou
text:
Enterprise adoption of AI is accelerating of off a relatively low base. It‚Äôs still very shallow and narrow in breadth despite the high public visibility of AI usage by its most ardent advocates. Most people are still barely using AI tools at their disposal. This is about to change in an explosive way. The macro impact of enterprise AI adoption, which will be first order and massive, is yet to be felt, if at all. 

For better understanding of directions of the macroeconomy, focus more on the potential impacts of AI and less on traditional cyclical indicators.

Build-in-public is probably the wrong move for startups, where the attention they command is finite

quotedTweet.author: BuccoCapital Bloke
quotedTweet.text:
Here‚Äôs an incredibly simple bull case for the incumbent systems of record, or at least, a simple rebuttal of the seat loss + shrinking customer LTV bear case:

1. AI has actually expanded their TAM, which is now the opportunity to displace labor by charging for outcomes instead of seats
2. If a business currently spends $20-50 to close a support ticket, they are thrilled to pay 50 cents for AI to solve it, and potentially also have to hire fewer support reps. Similar dynamic with leads and business development reps 
3. No company actively wants to use another vendor. It is so so so so so much easier to just use your existing relationship and infrastructure 
4. Therefore, literally every customer just wants Salesforce or HubSpot or ServiceNow to just figure this out. They are rooting for them 
5. Even if they are testing other point solutions, they will absolutely switch if the SoR solution becomes good enough 
6. They just have to become good enough in the next 12-18 months. They probably will figure it out

author: Rohan Paul
text:
Columbia CS Prof explains why LLMs can‚Äôt generate new scientific ideas.

Bcz LLMs learn a structured ‚Äúmap‚Äù, Bayesian manifold, of known data and work well within it, but fail outside it. 
But true discovery means creating new maps, which LLMs cannot do.
https://t.co/PzI0YrTTeT

quotedTweet.author: Rohan Paul
quotedTweet.text:
Yann LeCun (@ylecun) just revealed why he left Meta, Why are LLMs an extremely narrow field, and how "World model" is the way to build really meaningful agentic future. üéØ

Beautiful and simple in 1.5 mints.

"I can‚Äôt imagine we can build agentic systems without those systems having the ability to predict, in advance, what the consequences of their actions are going to be. The way we act in the world is that we can predict the consequences of our actions, and that‚Äôs what allows us to plan.

So what is a world model? Given the state of an environment, a system you want to control at time t, and given an action or intervention you imagine taking, can you predict the state of the world (or the system) at time t + 1? If you can, that‚Äôs a world model. You don‚Äôt do this at a pixel level, if it‚Äôs video. You do this in an abstract representation space, and that‚Äôs a crucial key insight."

---

From 'AI House Davos" YT channel (full link in comment)

author: ADWEEK
steve hsu
text:
No one has shipped a pipeline with agents working productively with large token budgets on research problems like physics. 

https://t.co/dbrvxtyTu3 

The Generator-Verifier pipeline I discuss could be implemented similar to the backend of coding platforms like Cursor or Claude Code, but no one has done it yet except in special cases (eg DM CoScientist) that are not available to the general public. Also, it takes very expert evaluators to figure out whether an output is good or bad - eval for coding is more automatable (math may fall in this category, for specific proofs but not new conceptualization).

author: The Kobeissi Letter
text:
BREAKING: Details of the historic trade deal between India and the EU have emerged:

1. Eliminates tariffs on ~90% of goods trade between EU and India

2. Set to double EU goods exports to India by 2032

3. Tariffs on cars from EU to India cut from 110% to 10%

4. Tariffs on wines from EU to India cut from 150% to 20%-30%

5. Tariffs on jewelry and textiles from India to EU cut to 0%

6. Tariffs on furniture, chemicals, leather, and metals from India to EU cut to 0%

This deal took nearly 20 years to reach and is being called the "mother of all deals."

India and the EU are looking to diversify away from the US.

author: Alex Finn
text:
ClawdBot is dead. Moltbot has arrived.

I don‚Äôt blame Anthropic for doing this at all

It‚Äôs fairly obvious this was going to happen. Anthropic has been coming after anyone using their trademarks, as they 100% should. You must protect your IP

Would not be surprised if they nuke using Claude oAuth too

What‚Äôs beautiful about Moltbot though is it‚Äôs open source and built to be customized

The most fun part is renaming it and building your own interfaces for everything

I rebuilt my own chat screen, project management screen, memory storage, interface, everything

You wouldn‚Äôt have even known it was ClawdBot.

If you haven‚Äôt rebuilt everything already get to that today

Long live Moltbot

Clawd ‚Üí Molty

New handle: @moltbot
Same mission: AI that actually does things.

author: Zephyr
text: OpenAI has been doing this for months now

quotedTweet.author: elie
quotedTweet.text:
15T is the same budget than kimi k2 initial pre training, afaik this is the first time that a team openly use a previous checkpoint to build an even stronger model

we'll keep seeing more and more of this "mid training" intervention to change arch, modalities, better long context, better agentic data.. 

this is very exciting and make it possible for other company to join the race (cursor?) thanks to provider like kimi (and others like deepseek, meituan, zai,...) releasing the base model

author: Paragon
text: Give your AI agents access to dozens of external apps and 1000+ read/write actions, instantly. With ActionKit, your AI agents will no longer be stuck relying on out-of-date context to generate responses.

author: John Coogan
text: Clawdbot: AI enters the Napster era

author: anita
text:
I think I‚Äôm using @clawdbot a little differently than most people. I'm not sharing any of my credentials or giving access to my personal local files. 

Instead, I set Ava to be a totally separate ‚Äúperson‚Äù with her own Apple ID, phone number, Google account, and even its own dedicated Mac Mini. With this, she can create her own accounts with apps like Vercel or Amazon or setup an X account (which she did: hi @avareed_1994) to help me with my tasks.

I only share things like reminders, our messaging chat, and calendar access, so it can text me, order groceries, and keep me accountable to go to the gym.. and anything else we figure out in the meantime

I know that means I‚Äôm missing some powerful persona/work automations for now, but I‚Äôd rather move slower than worry about security. 

and also, this is still so powerful and fun

author: vas
text: It bothers me deeply that OpenAI has no response to Claude Code, even now

author: Mr. Lobsterü¶û
text:
ü¶û BIG NEWS: We've molted!

Clawdbot ‚Üí Moltbot
Clawd ‚Üí Molty

Same lobster soul, new shell. Anthropic asked us to change our name (trademark stuff), and honestly? "Molt" fits perfectly - it's what lobsters do to grow.

New handle: @moltbot
Same mission: AI that actually does things.

author: BURKOV
text:
This paper discusses methods to extend LLMs into interactive agentic systems that incorporate planning, tool use, and search.

The authors from Meta, Amazon, Deepmind, and other top private and public labs consider in-context approaches that adapt during inference without altering weights and post-training methods that refine the model through reinforcement learning.

Read with an AI tutor: https://t.co/E4jknoWZ9f

Read alone: https://t.co/sWGups581J

author: Cato Networks
text: GenAI adoption didn‚Äôt follow protocol‚Äîit followed curiosity. Productivity tools are bypassing security, exposing massive risks. Legacy stacks weren‚Äôt built for this. Our eBook gives IT and security leaders clarity on Shadow AI, key questions, and architecture to control it.

author: Chris Bakke
text: Watching my friends spend $1500 and 30 hours of their time setting up an AI chatbot that summarizes the weather: https://t.co/6IcD6o3mBW

author: Andrew Rush
text:
It's astonishing to me how many people are still sleeping on how big Deadlock is going to be over the next few years. 

Release Deadlock is likely to hit 1.5-2M CCU on steam.  

Getting in on Deadlock now is the gaming equivalent of buying Apple stock pre-iPhone.  But many won't.

author: BURKOV
text: Stop reading AI-generated code. It's no longer for humans.

Don‚Äôt get me wrong. I‚Äôm having fun building with AI.

But the code AI produces is atrocious.

I‚Äôm just surprised that such bad code still works.
